bibl.title: Letter from Theodore C. Lyster to Laura Armistead Carter, September 14, 1925

div1.p: Lyster expresses his appreciation for Henry Carter's life and work.

div1.head: Letter from Theodore C. Lyster to Laura Armistead Carter, September 14, 1925
div1.opener:
9-14-25
THEODORE C. LYSTER, M. D.
EUGENE R. LEWIS, M. D.
ISAAC H. JONES, M. D.
SAMUEL D. INGHAM, M. D.
1920 WILSHIRE BOULEVARD
LOS ANGELES
My dear Laura,
div1.p:
Florence Read telegraphed
me a copy of your wire to them. Your
dear father had to leave us after all! I did so hope
he could go on having close calls and still
live. Those who have known you too as I have these
many years, can realize to some extent your loss
and the braving with which you will meet it. We
all share your sorrow more than we can say.
years of close association made me look
to your father as I have to few men. He made
his knowledge available for the use of his friends
and it was inexplanabible. What a joy to have
had such a father! Much as you will surely miss
him you have been fortunate in having him for
longer than it has been that of most of us. My feelings
are relieved to some extent when I look back at
the many hours and know I was fortunate to
have them with him. Sometime when you can,
write me of your plans, and should I be of
any assistance in helping you carry out
some of his wishes, you will call on me.
Love from all the Lysters to you and your brothers
in this sad time that comes to us all
